isis.stitle: AFC 95903 - Replace 30/30 Inch Rear Double Diaphragm Spring Brake Assemblies With 24/30 Inch Double Diaphragm Spring Brake Assemblies

afc.subject: Replace 30/30 Inch Rear Double Diaphragm Spring Brake Assemblies With 24/30 Inch Double Diaphragm Spring Brake Assemblies

geninfo.para: This AFC applies to 3900FC bus chassis with air brakes built from initial production through 05/03/1994.

The abovementioned bus chassis were built with 30/30 inch rear double diaphragm spring brake assemblies which meet all FMVSS requirements. Some customers have requested that the brake chambers on the rear of their vehicles be changed from 30/30 inch to 24/30 inch double diaphragm spring brake assemblies to better balance the brake system. This request was mainly associated with short wheelbase buses.
All 3900FC short wheelbase and a few long wheelbase buses were previously retrofit with 24/30 inch double diaphragm spring brake assemblies.

To provide better brake performance, International has decided to replace the 30/30 inch rear double diaphragm spring brake assemblies with 24/30 inch assemblies on 3900FC buses that still have 30/30 inch rear double diaphragm spring brake assemblies.

entry.para: 24/30 Inch MGM Left Rear Double Diaphragm Spring Brake Assembly
24/30 Inch MGM Right Rear Double Diaphragm Spring Brake Assembly

svcprocinfo.para: For complete service information on Double Diaphragm Spring Brakes, refer to GROUP 04 - PARKING BRAKES, in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.

warning.para: The spring brakes on this vehicle are tamper resistant and have been factory sealed for your protection. There are no user-serviceable parts inside the spring brake chambers. Never attempt to disassemble the spring brake chambers as serious personal injury or death could result from accidental sudden release of the high energy spring.
To prevent personal injury or death, the spring brake chamber must be caged before it is removed from the vehicle.

step1.para: Before releasing brakes, chock wheels of the vehicle to prevent the vehicle from rolling.
Remove the plastic end cap from the spring brake chamber ( Figure 1).
Use a 3/4-inch wrench to unscrew the release nut. Remove the nut, flat washer, and release bolt from their storage pocket on side of chamber ( Figure 2).

important.para: If these parts are not stored on the chamber, they must be obtained from vehicle tool box or service department, AS THE SPRING BRAKE CANNOT BE CAGED WITHOUT THEM.

step1.para: Insert the release bolt into the center hole of the spring brake chamber ( Figure 3) and, being sure that the formed end of the bolt has entered the hole in the piston inside the chamber, continue to insert the bolt until it bottoms out.

important.para: If you are not absolutely sure of correct bolt-to-piston engagement, repeat this step until you are sure.

step1.para: Turn the release bolt 1/4 turn clockwise and pull the bolt out to lock the formed end into the piston.

important.para: If the bolt does not lock into the position in less than 1/2 inch outward movement, repeat Steps 4 and 5 until you are sure it does lock.

step1.para: Hold the bolt locked into the piston. Install the flat washer and the release nut on the end of the release bolt, and thread the nut down against the flat washer until finger tight ( Figure 4).
Release vehicle parking brake with a minimum of 90 psi air pressure to the inlet port marked "SPRING BRAKE."
Thread the nut down against the flat washer until it is FINGER TIGHT. Three inches of bolt should extend above the nut ( Figure 5).
Completely exhaust air from the service and spring brake chambers.
After the spring brake has been caged as explained above, remove the cotter pin from the yoke pin and knock out the yoke pin.
Remove the air lines from the spring brake assembly ( Figure 6).

important.para: Be sure the air line from the spring brake inlet port is marked "SPRING BRAKE" for later re-installation reference.

step1.para: Use a 15/16-inch wrench and unscrew hex nuts ( Item 1, Figure 6) on mounting bolts and cautiously remove the chamber from the mounting bracket.

Before removing the yoke from the push rod, make sure the service brake is fully retracted into brakes "OFF" position. Measure from the bottom face of the service brake chamber to the center line of the yoke pin hole ( Figure 7).
Loosen the jam nut and remove the yoke and jam nut from the push rod.

svcsubproc.title: WITH BENDIX AUTOMATIC SLACK ADJUSTERS (With Easy-On Yoke Adapter Bushing)

step1.para: Remove as follows after the spring brake has been caged as explained above.

step2.para: Loosen the brake actuator push rod jam nut and run it back on the brake actuator push rod approximately 5/8 inch (17 mm).
Loosen the easy-on yoke adapter bushing and run it back on the bracket actuator push rod until it is free of the yoke.
Rotate the manual adjustment hex counterclockwise until the slack adjuster is clear of the brake actuator push rod.

note.para: Considerably more torque is required to rotate the manual adjustment hex counterclockwise than is necessary to rotate it clockwise. The required torque may be as high as 70 ft-lbs. (95 Nm).

step1.para: Remove the air lines from the spring brake assembly.

important.para: Be sure the air line from the spring brake inlet port is marked "SPRING BRAKE" for later re-installation reference.

step1.para: Use a 15/16-inch wrench and unscrew hex nuts ( Item 1, Figure 6) on mounting bolts and cautiously remove the chamber from the mounting bracket.

svcsubproc.title: WITH BENDIX AUTOMATIC SLACK ADJUSTERS (With Quick-Connect Yoke Adapter Bushing)

step1.para: Remove as follows after the spring brake has been caged as explained above.

step2.para: Rotate the slack adjuster manual adjustment hex counterclockwise until the brake actuator push rod just begins to move out of the actuator.

Pinch the legs of the retaining ring together and pull the slack adjuster away from the brake actuator push rod until the quick-connect adapter bushing is free of the yoke. Remove retaining ring from the adapter bushing.
Rotate the manual adjustment hex counterclockwise until the slack adjuster is clear of the brake actuator push rod.

note.para: Considerably more torque is required to rotate the manual adjustment hex counterclockwise than is necessary to rotate it clockwise. The required torque may be as high as 70 ft-lbs. (95 Nm).

step1.para: Remove the air lines from the spring brake assembly.

important.para: Be sure the air line from the spring brake inlet port is marked "SPRING BRAKE" for later re-installation reference.

step1.para: Use a 15/16-inch wrench and remove the hex nuts ( Item 1, Figure 6) on the mounting bolts and cautiously remove the chamber from the mounting bracket.

item.para: Remove the hex nuts and the flat washers on the mounting bolts of the new chamber ( Figure 6), clean the face of the mounting bracket and install the chamber on the bracket with close attention given to positioning the chamber air inlet ports for correct alignment to the vehicle air lines. Then install one flat washer and hex nut on each mounting bolt. Use a 15/16-inch hand wrench ( DO NOT USE AN IMPACT-TYPE WRENCH) to tighten the nuts to 100-115 ft-lbs. (136-156 Nm).

Apply Teflon tape or sealing compound to the hose fittings and re-install both of the air lines to the new chamber being sure each is mated to the correct air inlet port according to markings made earlier. Tighten fittings to 25 ft-lbs. (34 Nm).

step1.para: Before installing the yoke on the push rod, make sure the service brake is fully retracted into brakes "OFF" position. Install the jam nut, then the yoke on the new brake chamber actuator push rod. The yoke should be installed to the same dimension as was obtained in Step 4 of REMOVE, WITH ROCKWELL AUTOMATIC SLACK ADJUSTERS ( Figure 7).
Reconnect yoke to the slack adjuster, being sure that the correct diameter and length of yoke pin is installed into the correct hole in the slack adjuster. Secure the yoke pin with a new cotter pin.

Inspect the brake actuator push rod to be sure that it is working free, not binding and is square to the service brake chamber bottom within ±3 degrees in any direction at any point in the stroke of the chamber. If the push rod is not square, make corrections by repositioning the assembly on the mounting bracket. Tighten the jam nut against the yoke to 300-400 in-lbs. (34-45 Nm).

svcsubproc.title: WITH BENDIX AUTOMATIC SLACK ADJUSTERS (With Easy-On Yoke Adapter Bushing)

caution.para: Make sure the brake is completely released during the installation and adjustment procedures except when the instructions indicate that the brake must be applied. If the brake is not completely released when the yoke adapter bushing and slack adjuster are installed and adjusted, the slack adjuster will not adjust the brake correctly.

step1.para: Position the brake actuator push rod jam nut approximately 1-5/16 inches (33 mm) from the end of the brake actuator push rod. Thread the yoke adapter bushing on the brake actuator push rod until it is approximately 3/8 inch (9.5 mm) from the end of the brake actuator push rod end. Turn the manual adjustment hex clockwise until the adapter extends into the threaded bore of the yoke approximately 1/8 inch (3 mm). Thread the adapter into the yoke and tighten to 10 ft-lbs. (13.56 Nm).

Run the brake actuator push rod jam nut down against the easy-on adapter bushing. Hold the yoke adapter bushing hex with a wrench and tighten the jam nut to 300 to 400 in-lbs. (34 to 45 Nm) for the 1/2 inch-20 thread and 400 to 600 in-lbs. (45 to 68 Nm) for the 5/8 inch-18 thread.

svcsubproc.title: WITH BENDIX AUTOMATIC SLACK ADJUSTERS (With Quick-Connect Yoke Adapter Bushing)

caution.para: Make sure the brake is completely released during the installation and adjustment procedures except when the instructions indicate that the brake must be applied. If the brake is not completely released when the yoke adapter bushing and slack adjuster are installed and adjusted, the slack adjuster will not adjust the brake correctly.

step1.para: Position the brake actuator push rod jam nut approximately 1 inch (25 mm) from the end of the brake actuator push rod. Thread the yoke adapter bushing on the brake actuator push rod until it is flush with the end of the brake actuator push rod. Install the retaining ring on the adapter bushing, making certain it is in the adapter bushing groove. Turn the manual adjustment hex clockwise until the adapter bushing begins to enter the yoke. Fully compress the retaining ring "legs" and continue turning the manual adjustment hex until the adapter bushing is completely in the yoke.

Allow the retaining ring to expand into the corresponding groove in the yoke. Make certain the retaining ring is seated in both the yoke and the adapter bushing groove by manually pulling the slack adjuster arm, attempting to separate the adapter bushing and yoke.

Run the brake actuator push rod jam nut down against the quick-connect adapter bushing. Hold the yoke adapter bushing hex with a wrench and tighten the jam nut to 300 to 400 in-lbs. (34 to 45 Nm) for the 1/2 inch-20 thread and 400 to 600 in-lbs. (45 to 68 Nm) for the 5/8 inch-18 thread.

svcproc.title: CHECK FOR AIR LEAKS
svcproc.para: Use vehicle system air to charge the spring brake with full line pressure (minimum 100 psi). Use only soapy water (NEVER ANY TYPE OF OIL!) to inspect for air leaks at the air lines and fittings. If bubbles appear, tighten fittings slightly, but not over 25 ft-lbs. (34 Nm).

step1.para: With air applied on the spring brake, and exhausted from the service brake, remove release nut, washer and release bolt from the spring brake chamber. Replace these parts in their storage pocket ( Figure 10) on chamber (or in vehicle tool box if storage pocket is not present on chamber) and tighten nut against flat washer to 10 ft-lbs. (13.5 Nm).
Be sure the O-ring is installed in the plastic end cap ( Figure 11). Install the end cap ( Figure 1).

important.para: Before releasing the vehicle, check the brakes for proper operation and adjustment. Refer to GROUP 04 - PARKING BRAKE in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual for the type of spring brake assembly being serviced, for more detailed information on proper operation.

laborinfo.para: Operation number must appear on all claims.

entry.para: Replace a 30/30 inch double diaphragm spring brake assembly with a 24/30 inch double diaphragm spring brake assembly

claims.para: Expense is to be charged to Warranty. Claims are to be submitted in the normal manner, making reference to Authorized Field Change Number G-95903.

It is important that the coding be completed properly to assist in processing the warranty claim. Complete instructions will be found in the Warranty Manual, Section 7-1. Special attention should be given to items 39 through 44.

To assure this important improvement is made in a timely manner, all claims for G-95903 activity must be submitted by February 29, 1996, or within the normal warranty period for the vehicle, if after February 29, 1996.
